jyoshu

I was noticing an ad at the top of 4Forums where two men have an arm around the other's shoulder, and the caption was "Should They Wed?" The link goes to a survey.
 
 But it got me to thinking about something. It's interesting to me that because of homosexuality, our culture here in the U.S. can't have a picture of something like that without the presupposition that it must be about two gay people. I really think there are a lot of people in this country that, if they see two people walking arm on each shoulder, or (gasp) hand-in-hand, cant' get past the idea that the two have to be gay. Ironically I've noticed this tendency more among gay people than straight! It would be one thing if the ad had showed two me kissing, but this just has their arm around each other's shoulders. I wanted to somehow respond "maybe their just good friends!"
 
 I travel overseas quite a bit compared to most people. One of the places I have spent a good deal of time is in an African country. In that country (and most African countries) it is very common for men to walk around with their hands held, or arms around each others' shoulders. I experienced this firsthand (no pun intended) myself. I have to say it was great to be able to do that knowing that the culture around me didn't perceive it as something sexual. (And of course it wasn't.) If that picture had been displayed over there, no one would have thought anything about it, and the assumption would have been that the two guys were friends, not sexual lovers. One friend who's from over there remarked how Americans seem so stand-offish to him in general (he's visited the U.S. himself). He knows it's because of the prevalence of homosexuality over here and the effect it's had on our culture. To me it's sad that so many good things have been redefined into something more overtly sexual by homosexuality: some of our language and terms, and even the benign act of two men walking down the street with their arms around each other. We have a lot we could learn from our African neighbors--there is still a level of innocence there that has long been lost in our country.
joebrummer

 Your attempt here to blame homosexuals for the loss of non-sexual affection is pathetic. Men in america are still non-sexually affectionate towards each other. Youy cannot take cultural differences between Afica and America and blame them on homosexuals. That is called heterosexualism. Get a clue jyoushu.
jyoshu

Men in america are still non-sexually affectionate towards each other. 

 
 What planet have you been living on? 
 
 Do you actually think grown men walk down the street much holding hands these days here in the U.S., unless the are gay? Are you THAT out of touch with reality? For that matter, most gay people probably don't do that much either.
wsm2506

But it got me to thinking about something.

 
 That must have been an INCREDIBLE strain on you!!!!!
 
 
It's interesting to me that because of homosexuality, our culture here in the U.S. can't have a picture of something like that without the presupposition that it must be about two gay people. I really think there are a lot of people in this country that, if they see two people walking arm on each shoulder, or (gasp) hand-in-hand, cant' get past the idea that the two have to be gay.

 
 That "presupposition" is called "prejudice" and is based on homophobia like yours.
 
 
Ironically I've noticed this tendency more among gay people than straight!

 
 And just how many gay people do you actually know to enable you to reach such a conclusion? I dare say I know MANY more gay people than you, and I certainly don't see any such tendancy in stereotyping anyone. In fact, the vast number of gay people I know, having been subjected to discriminatory, prejudicial stereotyping by homophobes like you, tend to avoid stereotyping altogether.
 
 
 
I travel overseas quite a bit compared to most people. One of the places I have spent a good deal of time is in an African country. In that country (and most African countries) it is very common for men to walk around with their hands held, or arms around each others' shoulders. I experienced this firsthand (no pun intended) myself. I have to say it was great to be able to do that knowing that the culture around me didn't perceive it as something sexual. (And of course it wasn't.) If that picture had been displayed over there, no one would have thought anything about it, and the assumption would have been that the two guys were friends, not sexual lovers. One friend who's from over there remarked how Americans seem so stand-offish to him in general (he's visited the U.S. himself). He knows it's because of the prevalence of homosexuality over here and the effect it's had on our culture. To me it's sad that so many good things have been redefined into something more overtly sexual by homosexuality: some of our language and terms, and even the benign act of two men walking down the street with their arms around each other.
 
 
 
 I too travel quite often internationally, mostly in Southeast Asia; Tiawan, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Thailand. My partner is from Davao City, Philippines. I lived and worked in Mexico for 17 years. I see much more tolerance and acceptance of gay people there than here in the USA. You imply that homosexuality is more prevelant in the USA than in this un-named African country you allude to. I must disagree with you based on scientific studies ( as oppesed to your biased, prejudiced personal opinion) which indicate the incidence of homosexual orientation to be much the same throught different societies and geographic locations. Perhaps gays in the USA are more open than in the un-namrd Afircan country you allude to, but the factual evidence is that it is no more prevelant than anywhere else. What IS more prevelant is the homophobic prejudice openly displayed by people such as you. I personally know at least 5 gay people from Nigeria, and they describe a very robust gay comunnity there. Any redifinition of "so many good things" has been done by the homophobic people like you.
 
 
We have a lot we could learn from our African neighbors--there is still a level of innocence there that has long been lost in our country.

 
 We most certainly do: tolerance and understanding. Something which you seem totally incapable of.
wsm2506

What planet have you been living on? 
 
 Do you actually think grown men walk down the street much holding hands these days here in the U.S., unless the are gay? Are you THAT out of touch with reality? For that matter, most gay people probably don't do that much either.

 
 And why do you suppose that may be true? Is it because they fear harassment from homosexuals or harassment from homophobes like you?

So you don't watch sports do ya? Some butt cheek slaps and high fives, hugs after the touchdown. Frat boys are always hugging their frat brothers and no one thinks anything of it. infact you apparently didn't even notice it!
 
 Maybe you just don't get out much.

 I can honestly say I have no idea what he thinks. It is so hard to tell since his story seems to jump back and forth from supportive to outraged. It is like saying "Gays should have rights even though they are horrid diseased sinners who only care about getting some"
MrWriteLA

The poster has a long history of attempting to play both ends against the middle on other boards, which is why it's so easy to recognize him no matter his persona du jour.
 
 It usually boils down to: "You see how hateful you gays are not to acknowledge my support for you?" (He really likes the word "hateful," btw.)
 
 Wash, rinse, repeat with infinite variations.
 
 Just to let you know what you're in for.
Jaxian

I understand that Jyoshu has a view on homosexuality that we do not agree with, and I agree that his view does not make sense. But if we want people like this to see our side of things, responding in a harsh manner will not work. Human beings are naturally stubborn in their views, and responding harshly to a thread that was not intended to insult us will only make Jyoshu more certain that we are wrong.
 
 For my part, I agree with what has been posted here: that the reason males in our society are not as intimate is the unnatural fear of homosexuality. It is those who would suggest that homosexuality is morally wrong that are the cause of this, not those who suggest that it is morally acceptable.

BobNelson2

But it got me to thinking about something. It's interesting to me that because of homosexuality, our culture here in the U.S. can't have a picture of something like that without the presupposition that it must be about two gay people. 

 
 I actually agree with you that America is quite different from many other parts of the world with respect to same-sex intimacy. Actually, it's quite different from how it used to be just a few short decades ago. Male/male affection is disappearing, and it's a tragic and unnecessary loss. 
 
 The cause, however, is not homosexuality, but homophobia, sexism, and a general phobia about sex and sexuality -- male/female intimacy outside a romantic relationship is also quite rare here. There are plenty of places in the world where gay people have come out (and have more rights than we do in the U.S.) and the general culture has not become so suspicious of the nature of the relationship between two people. 
 
 The overriding influence on this issue seems to be a form of religiously-based Puritanism and prudery.
USA allthe Way

Male/male affection is disappearing, and it's a tragic and unnecessary loss. 

 
 
 What are we missing as a society if two heterosexual males don't hold hands?
BobNelson2

What are we missing as a society if two heterosexual males don't hold hands?

 
 Probably not a great deal, but if they also don't hug, or bump shoulders while walking side-by-side, or rough house, or goof around, or talk about their lives, or share their feelings, they're missing something important about being human.
 
 And don't try to tell me that that sort of thing is "pansy" stuff and doesn't matter. Same-sex physicality and emotional bonds that used to be more prevalent in American culture still exist in this society, and their benefits are considered important to both the individuals and the group. They persist in the military and in sports -- in other words, in areas "safe" from the perception of homosexuality, since homosexuality supposedly doesn't exist in those worlds. 
 
 The truth, of course, it that it does and that, in and of itself, it does nothing to diminish the bonds of friendship between guys except when one of those guys doesn't want others to think he's qu@@r.
billsco
